anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is from an order of the Central Government Labour Court, Rajasthan passed on February 14, 1966 on an application under S. 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act filed by the

facts.text: Labour Court awarded Rs. 40 p.m. supervisory allowance from 6th April 1954 to 31st December 1955 with consequential benefits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Labour Court allowed the respondent supervisory allowance at Rs. 40 p.m. with effect from 6th April, 1954 to 31st December, 1955 with consequential benefits. It is to be noted however

facts.text: Appellant conceded claim for periods 6th April 1954 to 12th July 1955 and 27th December 1955 to 31st December 1955 but contested 13th July 1955 to 27th December 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanghi appearing for the appellant was prepared to concede that so far as the periods 6th April, 1954 to 12th July, 1955 and 27th December, 1955 to 31st December, 1955 were concerned he was not contesting

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal upholding Labour Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

Appeal by special leave from the order dated February 14, 1966 of the Central Govt. Labour Court, Rajasthan, Jaipur in Misc. Application No. CLC-4 of 1964.

This appeal by special leave is from an order of the Central Government Labour Court, Rajasthan passed on February 14, 1966 on an application under S. 33-C  2  of the Industrial Disputes Act filed by the respondent, Hari Har Nath Bhargava, holding that the latter was entitled to supervisory allowance under paragraph 164  b   9  of the Sastry Award even for the period when the latter was number actually performing supervisory duties.

issues.text: Whether the respondent was entitled to supervisory allowance under paragraph 164(b)(9) of the Sastry Award even for the period when not actually performing supervisory duties, given the execution of a power of attorney conferring supervisory powers

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is from an order of the Central Government Labour Court, Rajasthan passed on February 14, 1966 on an application under S. 33-C  2  of the Industrial Disputes Act filed by the respondent, Hari Har Nath Bhargava, holding that the latter was entitled to supervisory allowance under paragraph 164  b   9  of the Sastry Award even for the period when the latter was number actually performing supervisory duties.

issues.text: Whether the application under S. 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act should be entertained despite being a stale claim with no statutory period of limitation

anchor.surface_text: A point was also taken that although no period of limitation is laid down by any statute with regard to applications under S. 33-C of the Act the respondents claim being a stale one should not be entertained.

issues.text: Whether the status for supervisory allowance is determined by the employee's designation or by the nature of duties and functions assigned, particularly where a power of attorney confers supervisory authority

anchor.surface_text: before a person can claim the supervisory special allowance, he must establish that he has discharged the duties and functions which are similar to 0r the same as the duties or functions assigned to supervisors coming under category 9. This decision Lloyds Bank Ltd. v. Panna Lal Gupta and others  1  also makes it clear that in deciding the status of an employee claiming the special allowance, the designation of the employee is number decisive and what determines the status is a consideration of the nature of the duties and functions assigned to the employee concerned.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Labour Court the underlying idea behind the said award was that when one general scale for clerical service had been provided in the award, it was thought just and proper that persons with special qualifications or skill required for discharging work carrying with it greater responsibility than the usual work should definitely get higher emoluments than the ordinary workmen. The Labour Court said that this did

court_response_anchor.surface_text: int had been taken in the written statement of the bank, it was number agitated before the Labour Court and further was number taken even in the speci

arguments.claim: To claim supervisory allowance must have discharged duties similar to supervisors under category 9 of Sastry Award

anchor.surface_text: In State Bank of Hyderabad v. V. A. Bhide this Court had to consider the claims of the respondents in that appeal for payment of special allowance granted to supervisors under what were known as the Sastry and Desai awards. ... before a person can claim the supervisory special allowance, he must establish that he has discharged the duties and functions which are similar to or the same as the duties or functions assigned to supervisors coming under category 9.

arguments.claim: Status for special allowance determined by nature of duties and functions assigned, not designation

anchor.surface_text: This decision Lloyds Bank Ltd. v. Panna Lal Gupta and others also makes it clear that in deciding the status of an employee claiming the special allowance, the designation of the employee is not decisive and what determines the status is a consideration of the nature of the duties and functions assigned to the employee concerned.

arguments.claim: Power of attorney execution accords status competent to discharge supervisory functions, continuing unless revoked, entitling to allowance even without constant actual performance

anchor.surface_text: In our view the payment of a special allowance is called for when an employee discharges duties of a supervisory nature or is accorded the status of a person competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character. If no power of attorney is executed as in this case but in fact the employee is asked to render services of a supervisory character and the employee does such work at the request of the bank, he becomes entitled to the allowance. Once however a power of attorney giving the wide powers of agency as was done in this case is executed, it should be held that the management had placed him in a category of persons with responsibility and the employee was to discharge the responsibility without any further request in that behalf.

arguments.claim: Power of attorney operative at any branch irrespective of location or capacity, transfer to Jaipur did not denude supervisory powers without notice

anchor.surface_text: But the power of attorney does not show that the bank thought it necessary to-clothe the respondent with the said powers only for discharging his duties when he was at Kota. The power of attorney was operative at any branch of the bank irrespective of the capacity which might be occupied by the respondent at a particular point of time. ... the respondent lost his responsibility or was denuded of the powers while he was at Jaipur. If he discharged any of the duties mentioned in the power of attorney the same would be lawful and would be binding on the bank.

holdings.text: The payment of a special allowance is called for when an employee discharges duties of a supervisory nature or is accorded the status of a person competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character. Once a power of attorney giving wide powers of agency is executed, the management has placed the employee in a category of persons with responsibility.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the payment of a special allowance is called for when an employee discharges duties of a supervisory nature or is accorded the status of a person competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character. If no power of attorney is executed as in this case but in fact the employee is asked to render services of a supervisory character and the employee does such work at the request of the bank, he becomes entitled to the allowance. Once however a power of attorney giving the wide powers of agency as was done in this case is executed, it should be held that the management had placed him in a category of persons with responsibility and the employee was to discharge the responsibility without any further request in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents requiring similar duties to supervisors under Sastry Award category 9; execution of PoA creates competent status without need for constant actual performance.

holdings.text: The power of attorney was operative at any branch of the bank irrespective of the capacity which might be occupied by the respondent at a particular point of time; transfer did not denude powers without notice.

anchor.surface_text: But the power of attorney does not show that the bank thought it necessary to-clothe the respondent with the said powers only for discharging his duties when he was at Kota. The power of attorney was operative at any branch of the bank irrespective of the capacity which might be occupied by the respondent at a particular point of time. It may be that at Jaipur there was a number of officers superior to the respondent who were empowered to discharge duties mentioned in the power of attorney but this does not necessarily lead to the inference that the respondent lost his responsibility or was denuded of the powers while he was at Jaipur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of PoA shows no branch-specific limitation; no evidence of revocation upon transfer to Jaipur.

holdings.text: The fact that he was not actually called upon to discharge such functions did not take away from his responsibility or status of a person competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character and we see no reason why he should be deprived of supervisory allowance unless the bank gave him notice that he was not to act on the power of attorney while at Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: If he discharged any of the duties mentioned in the power of attorney the same would be lawful and would be binding on the bank. The fact that he was not actually called upon to discharge such functions did not take away from his responsibility or status of a person ,competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character and we see no reason why he should be deprived of supervisory allowance unless the bank gave him notice that he was not to act on the power of attorney while at Jaipur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Status from PoA persists absent notice of countermand or cancellation; designation irrelevant, duties/functions determine status per precedents.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that the Labour Court had come to the correct conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Labour Court had come to the correct conclusion. Mr. Sanghi tried to urge the point that the Labour ,Court should not have entertained the application as being inordinately belated and that even though the Labour Court did not adjudicate on this point it was open- to the bank to urge it before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Labour Court's application of Sastry Award para 164(b)(9) based on continuing supervisory status from PoA.

holdings.text: We were not going to entertain this plea in view of the fact that although the point had been taken in the written statement of the bank, it was not agitated before the Labour Court and further was not taken even in the special leave petition.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanghi tried to urge the point that the Labour ,Court should not have entertained the application as being inordinately belated and that even though the Labour Court did not adjudicate on this point it was open- to the bank to urge it before us. We made it clear that we were not going to entertain this plea in view of the fact that although the point had been taken in the written statement of the bank, it was not agitated before the Labour Court and further was not taken even in the special leave petition. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation/delay point waived by not pressing before Labour Court or raising in special leave petition.

holdings.text: After the execution of the power of attorney the respondent was empowered to discharge functions which could only be described as supervisory in nature and unless there was a command or direction that he should not act thereon or unless the power of attorney was cancelled his authority to act in a supervisory capacity would continue in force.

anchor.surface_text: It is worthy of note that after the execution of the power of attorney the respondent was empowered to, discharge functions which could only be described as. supervisory in nature and unless there was a command or direction that he should not act thereon or unless the power of attorney was cancelled his authority, to act in a supervisory capacity would continue in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PoA confers supervisory authority that persists unless explicitly countermanded or revoked.

precedents.citation: State Bank of Hyderabad v. V. A. Bhide 1969 2 L.L.J. 713

anchor.surface_text: This Court had to deal with a case where an identical question arose. In State Bank of Hyderabad v. V. A. Bhide  1  this Court had to companysider the claims of the respondents in that appeal for payment of special allowance granted to supervisors under what were known as the Sastry and Desai awards. It was there companytended on behalf ,of the appellant bank that in order to claim the supervisory allowance the parties must establish that the main or essential duties entrusted to them and actually discharged by  1 1969 2 L.L.J. 713.

precedents.citation: Lloyds Bank Ltd. v. Panna Lal Gupta and others 1961 1 L.L.J. 18

anchor.surface_text: This decision Lloyds Bank Ltd. v. Panna Lal Gupta and others  1  also makes it clear that in deciding the status of an employee claiming the special allowance, the designation of the employee is number decisive and what determines the status is a companysideration of the nature of the duties and functions assigned to the employee companycerned. In our view the payment of a special allowance is called for when an employee discharges duties of a supervisory nature or is accorded the status of a person companypetent to discharge functions of a supervisory character.

precedents.cited_proposition: in deciding the status of an employee claiming the special allowance, the designation of the employee is not decisive and what determines the status is a consideration of the nature of the duties and functions assigned to the employee concerned

edges.explanation: Holding on payment for duties or status supports final affirmation of Labour Court
Holding h1 sets out the conditions for payment of supervisory allowance based on discharge of duties or status, directly addressing the issue of entitlement absent actual performance of duties.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the payment of a special allowance is called for when an employee discharges duties of a supervisory nature or is accorded the status of a person competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character. If no power of attorney is executed as in this case but in fact the employee is asked to render services of a supervisory character and the employee does such work at the request of the bank, he becomes entitled to the allowance. Once however a power of attorney giving the wide powers of agency as was done in this case is executed, it should be held that the management had placed him in a category of persons with responsibility and the employee was to discharge the responsibility without any further request in that behalf.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed.
ye to the companyrect companyclusion. Mr. Sanghi tried to urge the point that the Labour ,Court should number have entertained the application as bein

edges.explanation: Power of attorney operative irrespective of posting supports affirmation
Holding h2 addresses continuity of supervisory status via power of attorney despite transfer or change in capacity, relevant to entitlement during non-performance periods.

anchor.surface_text: But the power of attorney does not show that the bank thought it necessary to-clothe the respondent with the said powers only for discharging his duties when he was at Kota. The power of attorney was operative at any branch of the bank irrespective of the capacity which might be occupied by the respondent at a particular point of time. It may be that at Jaipur there was a number of officers superior to the respondent who were empowered to discharge duties mentioned in the power of attorney but this does not necessarily lead to the inference that the respondent lost his responsibility or was denuded of the powers while he was at Jaipur.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed.
e it clear that we were number going to entertain this plea in view of the fact that although the point had been taken in the written statement of the

edges.explanation: Non-exercise of functions does not remove status supports affirmation

anchor.surface_text: If he discharged any of the duties mentioned in the power of attorney the same would be lawful and would be binding on the bank. The fact that he was not actually called upon to discharge such functions did not take away from his responsibility or status of a person ,competent to discharge functions of a supervisory character and we see no reason why he should be deprived of supervisory allowance unless the bank gave him notice that he was not to act on the power of attorney while at Jaipur.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 concludes by affirming the Labour Court's resolution of the entitlement issue.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Labour Court had come to the correct conclusion. Mr. Sanghi tried to urge the point that the Labour ,Court should not have entertained the application as being inordinately belated and that even though the Labour Court did not adjudicate on this point it was open- to the bank to urge it before us.

edges.explanation: h4 upholding Labour Court correct conclusion implicitly addresses i2 by sustaining order despite limitation objection

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanghi tried to urge the point that the Labour ,Court should not have entertained the application as being inordinately belated and that even though the Labour Court did not adjudicate on this point it was open- to the bank to urge it before us. We made it clear that we were not going to entertain this plea in view of the fact that although the point had been taken in the written statement of the bank, it was not agitated before the Labour Court and further was not taken even in the special leave petition. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.
